reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s Section 2 move: that “future catastrophes are easy” and that a single moral flaw can wipe out most value, supported by a cross-perspective list of plausible-seeming catastrophes (incl. the animal farming claim). This is fairly central to motivating “no easy eutopia” (it underwrites the fragility/multiplicative-factor story), though the overall position also has a substantial independent Section 3 argument about bounded/unbounded value functions and fussiness; even if Section 2 were weakened, the essay’s main conclusion could still be supported, so centrality is moderate (~0.55).

Strength is limited because the critique mostly complains about lack of causal model/operationalization/falsifiability for claims that are largely philosophical/structural rather than empirical predictions. The essay is not primarily offering empirical forecasts but arguing that (i) many plausible moral perspectives deem apparently good worlds deeply flawed, and (ii) there are many dimensions along which value could be lost even under “common-sense utopia,” suggesting narrow targets. Pointing out that policymakers lack “testable discriminators” doesn’t directly refute that conceptual claim. It does somewhat pressure the rhetorical force of calling these “easy” and the dramatic animal-farming comparison, so it modestly weakens that portion.

Correctness is mixed: it’s fair that the animal-farming line is underspecified quantitatively (what welfare measure/weights would make it outweigh human gains) and that the essay often relies on illustrative lists rather than a calibrated probabilistic model. But claims like “epistemic sabotage” and “inflates moral uncertainty into paralysis” overreach and mischaracterize the essay’s aim (it explicitly continues to discuss steering/convergence rather than endorsing paralysis), lowering correctness.

Clarity is good: it identifies specific target claims and alleges a specific failure mode (no update rules/operationalization). Dead weight is low but nonzero due to loaded rhetoric (“epistemic sabotage”). It is mostly a single issue: the objection that the argument is non-operational/non-falsifiable and hence action-guidingly weak.
title: Lack of falsifiable criteria turns catastrophe claims into unfalsifiable rhetoric
